Title:
Bridging population and phylogenetic approaches to the
evolution of complex traits.
Abstract:
I discuss two approaches to the problem of how an
integrated complex of traits has evolved. The population approach
combines functional, comparative, and genetic studies aimed at
understanding the environmental selection pressures that have favored
the evolution of the complex. The phylogenetic approach uses estimates
of genealogical relationships between species to truce the historical
sequence of changes leading to the diversity of modern forms. A major
concern is how intrinsic structural features of ancestral species
directed subsequent evolutionary pattern. The two approaches are more
complementary than antagonistic, and I illustrate how a greater
synthesis of the two viewpoints can yield insights into evolutionary
events. The benefits of a joint approach are especially evident in
comparative study. where presentday differences between taxa can be
partitioned into components. one representing the effects of the current
environment and another of prior history. I give examples of studies of
adaptation that have benefited from a phylogenetic perspective. I also
show how population models of natural selection can be valuable in the
interpretation of historical events and may he useful in the
construction of phylogenies.
